Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Understanding How Seabird Guano Impacts Nutrient Availability and Plant Community Composition in Montane Terrestrial Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
To better understand plant-animal and terrestrial-marine linkages, the project will study the input of nitrogen (N) by seabirds into forested areas in New Zealand. This is an important dynamic to understand as some islands are undergoing predator removal and native habitat and seabird restoration, while others continue to experience seabird declines. This work will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. David Towns of the Auckland University of Technology (AUT). Dr. Towns has over 20 years of experience studying ecosystems in New Zealand as well as many years working with seabird islands and their restoration. Primary research questions include: how do seabird population densities impact nutrient subsidies, how much marine-sourced N do the plants utilize, and do these seabird induced changes in the soil and plants impact the vegetation community structure. It is hypothesized that as seabird burrow density increases, N from seabirds will increase, and vegetation community structure in seabird communities will change, becoming more significantly composed of native plants adapted to utilize the pulsed subsidies provided by the seabirds. This New Zealand research will be compared with previous work in Hawaii to better understand linkages of the marine-seabird-terrestrial ecosystem as seabirds? populations decline across the globe.

The N isotope composition of soil and leaves will be measured to understand how N brought from the ocean to the terrestrial system moves through the ecosystem. High d15N values may serve as a signature of marine source of N. A two end member, one isotope mixing model will be used to assess the percentage of N in soil and leaves that is from a marine source, i.e. seabirds. Vegetation community structure will also be measured to determine if there is an appreciable difference between seabird and non-seabird areas in terms of community composition. This award is funded in collaboration with the Royal Society of New Zealand.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Julia Rowe, PH.D. Candidate, Natural Resources and Environmental Management,

University of Hawaii at Manoa, USA

In collaboration with Dr. David Towns, Associate Professor, Applied Conservation, Auckland University of Technology, Auckland, NZ

Funded jointly by U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF), EAPSI program and the New Zealand Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment (MBIE)

 

To better understand plant-animal and terrestrial-marine linkages, I was interested in the input of nitrogen (N) by seabirds into montane systems in New Zealand. I studied the black petrel (Procellaria parkinsoni) colony on Mount Hobson, Great Barrier Island to better understand the relationship between allochthonous nutrients delivered by seabirds and the ecosystem where they nest. In a similar study in Hawaii, I found that seabirds, even in very low numbers make a significant contribution to soil nutrient cycling that then alters plant nutrient content at least for some dominant species. My primary research questions to be addressed with this study in NZ were (i) How does seabird population density impact nutrient subsidies? (ii) How does vegetation use marine source nitrogen in seabird colonies in New Zealand vs Hawaii? Hypothesis for these questions: 1) as seabird burrow density increases; nitrogen sourced from the ocean will increase; 2) marine nitrogen will be higher in plants in seabird areas in New Zealand than non-seabird areas as well as seabird areas in Hawaii. In the broader sense it is important to understand the linkages of the marine — seabird — terrestrial ecosystem as seabirds face population declines across the globe.

Mount Hobson, Great Barrier Island, NZ is home to a dense population of black petrels. Black petrels nest in burrows in high elevation mountain sides. Study site were located in the petrel colony in forest of Mnt. Hobson and the control site was located in upper elevation forest in the Honua Mountain Range of the Southern Regional Parks, administered by the Auckland Council. Plots in the seabird colony were distributed through three levels of burrow density; low, medium and high.

Values of marine nitrogen were determined for the top 10 cm of soil, and selected plant species. Plant species included: Melicytus ramiflorus, Metrosideros perforata, Coprosma grandiflora, Raukaua simplex, Melicytus macrophyllus, Rhabdothamnus solandri, and Quintinia serrata. Leaves were collected from every plot that the species occurred in, not all species occurred in all of the plots.

No differences were seen between seabird and non-seabird or between treatments except for the endemic shrub; matata or New Zealand gloxinia (Rhabdothamnus solandri) which expressed progressively higher marine nitrogen values in areas of progressively dense burrow colonies. It is a long living, flowing shrub, that requires birds for pollination. This plant expressed higher marine nitrogen values in areas with more seabirds, meaning that of the nitrogen in its leaves, more of it was from a marine source in areas with than plants in areas with fewer burrows.  This is one small piece in the puzzle of understanding how seabird nesting impacts the host ecosystem. This is more important as seabird population numbers are decreasing globally and massive efforts are underway to restore some seabirds to suitable and/or historical habitat. To understand what impact these organisms have on their environment and what may be lost if these birds are lost is critical to understanding and conserving ecosystems as a whole. 

 


Last Modified: 07/01/2016
Modified by: Julia A Rowe
